channel.title: PLANit â€“ Documentation
channel.description: Recent content in Documentation on PLANit

item.title: Docs: .activate(+)
item.description:
Description

This .activate(+) method allows you to activate different types of output for your assignment given some output formatter enum that you provide

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, activate your (additional) outputs via instance.activate(OutputFormatter.<enum>).

Return type

N/A

See also

OutputFormatter.<enum> for supported output formatters
PLANit.deactivate(+) for de-activating output formatters

Parameters

Parameter Compulsory Default Type Description
OutputFormatter.<enum> yes N/A Enum Type of output formatter to apply

Example 1


# prep
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

# Without any explicit activation of any output formatter, PLANit will automatically 
# activate PLAN_IO upon the creation of any traffic assignment type. No explicit action needed
# The output formatter is then accessible via the .output property
planit_instance.output.<some method>

Example 2


# prep
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

# Activate memory based output formatting on top of the default persistence
planit_instance.activate(OutputFormatter.MEMORY)
# access via .memory property to configure further
planit_instance.memory.<some method>

item.title: Docs: .activate_output(+)
item.description:
Description

This .activate_output allows you to activate various types of output to be generated as part of the assignment results. Do note that the more output is being activated, the more effort the simulation must make to gather this information causing various degrees of performance loss.

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, and instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC) is invoked.

The .activate_output method can then be applied via instance.assignment.activate_output(OutputType.<enum>).

Return type

N/A

See also

Traditional static traffic assignment for information on this method’s class instance

Parameters

Parameter Compulsory Default Type Description
OutputType.<enum> yes N/A Enum Choice of output type to activate

Example 1


# Choose to run PLANit with a traditional static traffic assignment method
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

# activate path outputs
planit_instance.assignment.activate_output(OutputType.PATH)

item.title: Docs: .deactivate(+)
item.description:
Description

This .deactivate(+) method allows you to de-activate types of output for your assignment given some output formatter enum that you provide. Only when an output formatter is activated, de-activating it will result in a de-activation, otherwise the call is imsply ignored.

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, de-activate an output formatter via instance.deactivate(OutputFormatter.<enum>).

Return type

N/A

See also

OutputFormatter.<enum> for supported output formatters
PLANit.activate(+) for activating output formatters

Parameters

Parameter Compulsory Default Type Description
OutputFormatter.<enum> yes N/A Enum Type of output formatter to de-activate

Examples


# prep
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

# Without any explicit activation of any output formatter, PLANit will automatically 
# activate PLANIT_IO upon the creation of any traffic assignment type. No explicit action needed
# So, you can deactivate it as follows, resulting in no output for your run
planit_instance.deactivate(TrafficAssignment.PLANIT_IO)
# likely you want to activate another output type instead
planit_instance.activate(TrafficAssignment.MEMORY)

item.title: Docs: .run()
item.description:
Description

This .run() method conducts the actual traffic assignment run. Make sure all configuration has been applied before calling this method. Results are only available after invoking this method.

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, conduct the run via instance.run().

Return type

N/A

See also

N/A

Parameters

None

Example 1


# prep
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

#
# <Perform further configuration here>
#

# conduct the simulation
planit_instance.run()

#
# <Do something with results>
#

item.title: Docs: .set(+)
item.description:
Description

This .set allows you to set the choice for components used in traditional static assigment such as:

  • How to compute cost for the transport network (split in physical and virtual cost)
  • How to perform smoothing between iterations

Depending on the chosen option the assignment performs differently

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, and instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC) is invoked.

The .set method can then be used via instance.assignment.set(<AssignmentType>.<enum>), where the choices for the various parameters are outlined in the parameter section

Return type

N/A

See also

Traditional static traffic assignment for information on this method’s class instance

Parameters

Parameter Compulsory Default Type Description
<AssignmentType>.<enum> yes N/A Enum Set choice for a component

Each of the options for the <AssignmentType>.<enum> parameter are listed below:

<AssignmentType>.<enum> Description
PhysicalCost.<enum> Type of link performance function to apply as the physical cost, i.e., travel time
VirtualCost.<enum> Type of cost to apply as the virtual cost, i.e., travel time from zone-to-physical-network
Smoothing.<enum> Type of smoothing to apply between iterations

Physical Cost Support

Traditional static assignment currently supports the following PhysicalCost types:

  • PhysicalCost.BPR

Virtual Cost Support

Traditional static assignment currently supports the following Virtual cost types:

  • VirtualCost.FIXED
  • VirtualCost.SPEED

Smoothing Support

Traditional static assignment currently supports the following smoothing types:

  • Smoothing.MSA

Example 1


# Choose to run PLANit with a traditional static traffic assignment method
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

# set physical cost to BPR link performance function
planit_instance.assignment.set(PhysicalCost.BPR)

# configure the instantiated property
planit_instance.assignment.physical_cost.<call method>

Example 2


# Choose to run PLANit with a traditional static traffic assignment method
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

# set virtual cost to a constant value for all connectors (zone-to-physical network connections)
planit_instance.assignment.set(VirtualCost.FIXED)

# configure the instantiated property
planit_instance.assignment.virtual_cost.<call method>

Example 3


# Choose to run PLANit with a traditional static traffic assignment method
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

# set virtual cost to a constant value for all connectors (zone-to-physical network connections)
planit_instance.assignment.set(Smoothing.MSA)

# configure the instantiated property
planit_instance.assignment.smoothing.<call method>

item.title: Docs: .set(+)
item.description:
Description

This .set allows you to set the type of traffic assignment to use on your planit instance.

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, set your choice of assignment via instance.set(TrafficAssignment.<enum>).

Return type

N/A

See also

TrafficAssignment.<enum> for supported assignment types

Parameters

Parameter Compulsory Default Type Description
TrafficAssignment.<enum> yes N/A Enum Type of traffic assignment to apply

Example 1


# Choose to run PLANit with a traditional static traffic assignment method
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

item.title: Docs: .assignment
item.description:
Description

The .assignment property allows access to the assignment instance for configuration purposes. Depending on the chosen assignment different methods and properties will be exposed. Only a single assignment is available for each planit instance.

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, you instantiate the assignment via instance.set(TrafficAssignment.<enum>). After this, the assignment instance can be accessed via this property, e.g., instance.assignment

Return type

Instance of Class AssignmentWrapper in Wrappers.py

See also

TrafficAssignment.<enum> for supported assignment types
.set(+) on how to instantiate this property

To find out more about the options available on any of the assignment implementations, please refer to the assignment section of this manual

Example 1

Create a traditional static traffic assignment. The planit_instance.assignment.<call method> must call a method available on the traditional static assignment class, since this is the instance it returns


# Create instance, set traffic assignment type, access the assignment instance
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC)
planit_instance.assignment.<call method>

item.title: Docs: .demands
item.description:
Description

The .demands property allows access to the in-memory version of the parsed input demands

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, you access the demands via instance.demands.

Return type

Instance of Class DemandsWrapper in Wrappers.py

See also

Demands describes the options available on the demands implementation

Example 1


# Create instance and access in-memory demands instance
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.demands.<call method>

item.title: Docs: .memory
item.description:
Description

The .memory property allows access to the results in-memory. Configuration specific to this output formatter is also accessible via this property

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, and the memory output formatter has been activated via instance.activate(OutputFormatter.MEMORY) ,you access the memory output formatter via instance.memory.

Return type

Instance of Class MemoryOutputFormatterWrapper in Wrappers.py

See also

OutputFormatter.<enum> for all available output formatters
PLANit.activate(+) to see how to activate an output formatter
PLANit.deactivate(+) to see how to de-activate an output formatter Memory output formatter describes the options available on the memory output formatter implementation

Example 1


# prep
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC)

#
# <other configuration>
#

planit_instance.activate(OutputFormatter.MEMORY)
planit_instance.memory.<call method>

item.title: Docs: .network
item.description:
Description

The .network property allows access to the in-memory version of the parsed input physical transport network

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, you access the network via instance.network.

Return type

Instance of Class PhysicalNetworkWrapper in Wrappers.py

See also

Network describes the options available on the physical network implementation

Example 1


# Create instance and access in-memory network instance
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.network.<call method>

item.title: Docs: .output
item.description:
Description

The .output property allows access to specific configuration options on the native PLANit output formatter. The native formatter persists results to disk using csv files with additional meta data provided in xml files.

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, the (default) output formatter is accessible via instance.output.

Return type

Instance of Class PlanItOutputFormatterWrapper in Wrappers.py

See also

OutputFormatter.<enum> for all available output formatters
PLANit.activate(+) to see how to activate an output formatter
PLANit.deactivate(+) to see how to de-activate an output formatter
Default output formatter describes the options available on the default output formatter implementation

Example 1


# prep
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC)

#
# <other configuration>
#

planit_instance.output.<call method>

item.title: Docs: .physical_cost
item.description:
Description

The .physical_cost property allows access to the chosen physical cost assuming it has been set. It can be used for configuration specific to the chosen type.

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC) is invoked, and the physical cost has been set via instance.assignment.set(PhysicalCost.<enum>).

The instance.assignment.physical_cost method can then be used to retrieve the chosen physical cost instance

Return type

Instance of Class PhysicalCostWrapper in Wrappers.py

See also

Traditional static traffic assignment for information on this method’s class instance
PhysicalCost.<enum> for all available physical cost options
PhysicalCost Describes the options available for all available physical cost implementations

Example 1


# prep
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC)

#
# <other configuration>
#

planit_instance.set(PhysicalCost.BPR)
planit_instance.physical_cost.<call method>

#
# <other configuration>
#

item.title: Docs: .zoning
item.description:
Description

The .zoning property allows access to the in-memory version of the parsed input zoning structure

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, you access the zoning via instance.zoning.

Return type

Instance of Class ZoningWrapper in Wrappers.py

See also

Zoning describes the options available on the zoning structure implementation

Example 1


# Create instance and access in-memory zoning structure instance
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.zoning.<call method>

item.title: Docs: OutputFormatter.<Enum>
item.description:
Description

Class exposing supported output formatters as enums.

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, you activate an output formatter via instance.activate(OutputFormatter.<enum>). After this, the chosen formatter can be accessed as outlined in the Access instance via column in Fields

See also

PLANit.activate(+) PLANit.deactivate(+)

Type

Class OutputFormatter in Enums.py

Fields

<enum> Fields Description Access instance via
PLANIT_IO PLANit’s native output format instance.output
MEMORY Stores results in memory instance.memory

Examples


# prep
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

# Without any explicit activation of any output formatter, PLANit will automatically 
# activate PLAN_IO upon the creation of any traffic assignment type. No explicit action needed
# The output formatter is then accessible via the x.output property
planit_instance.output.<some method>

Example 2


# prep
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

# Activate memory based output formatting on top of the default persistence
planit_instance.activate(OutputFormatter.MEMORY)
# access memory based output formatter instance to configure further
planit_instance.memory.<some method>

item.title: Docs: OutputType.<Enum>
item.description:
Description

Class exposing the available Output type types as enums. When used to activate an output type on a traffic assignment instance it will trigger output results of that type to be generated and further configuration options to be exposed via the relevant properties on the assignment instance.

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, and instance.set(TrafficAssignment.<enum>) is invoked.

Then the output type types can be activated on the assignment using instance.assignment.activate_output(OutputType.<enum>) utilising one of the Enum Fields.

See also

Assignment for the various assignment methods where one can activate output types and how to retrieve the related output configuration instance for further configuration.

Type

Class OutputType in Enums.py

Fields

<enum> Fields Description Access instance via
LINK Represents link outputs instance.assignment.link_configuration
OD Represents origin-destination outputs instance.assignment.od_configuration
PATH Represents path outputs instance.assignment.path_configuration

Example 1


# Choose to run PLANit with a traditional static traffic assignment method
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

# activate origin-destination outputs to be generated
planit_instance.assignment.activate_output(OutputType.OD)

# configure the instantiated property
planit_instance.assignment.od_configuration.<call method>

Example 2


# Choose to run PLANit with a traditional static traffic assignment method
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

# activate path outputs to be generated
planit_instance.assignment.activate_output(OutputType.PATH)

# configure the instantiated property
planit_instance.assignment.path_configuration.<call method>

Example 3


# Choose to run PLANit with a traditional static traffic assignment method
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

# link outputs are activated by default
# configure the instantiated property
planit_instance.assignment.link_configuration.<call method>

item.title: Docs: PhysicalCost.<Enum>
item.description:
Description

Class exposing the available Physical Cost types as enums.

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, and instance.set(TrafficAssignment.<enum>) is invoked.

Then the physical cost type can be set on the assignment using instance.assignment.set(PhysicalCost.<enum>) utilising one of the Enum Fields.

The instantiated object is the accessible via instance.assignment.physicalcost

It is possible that not every physical cost method is supported by every traffic assignment method. The documentation of the chosen traffic assignment method will indicate what physical cost methods are supported.

See also

Assignment for the various assignment methods where one can set the physical cost on and how to retrieve the instantiated physical cost object.

Type

Class PhysicalCost in Enums.py

Fields

<enum> Fields Description
BPR Bureau of Public Roads1 link performance function

1 United States, Bureau of Public Roads, Traffic assignment manual. (1964). Washington.

Example 1


# Choose to run PLANit with a traditional static traffic assignment method
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

# set physical cost to BPR link performance function
planit_instance.assignment.set(PhysicalCost.BPR)

# configure the instantiated property
planit_instance.assignment.physical_cost.<call method>

item.title: Docs: Smoothing.<Enum>
item.description:
Description

Class exposing the available smoothing types as enums.

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, and instance.set(TrafficAssignment.<enum>) is invoked.

Then the smoothing type can be set on the assignment using instance.assignment.set(Smoothing.<enum>) utilising one of the Enum Fields.

The instantiated object is then accessible via instance.assignment.smoothing

It is possible that not every smoothing method is supported by every traffic assignment method. The documentation of the chosen traffic assignment method will indicate what smoothing methods are supported.

See also

Assignment for the various assignment methods where one can set the smoothing on and how to retrieve the instantiated smoothing object.

Type

Class Smoothing in Enums.py

Fields

<enum> Fields Description
MSA Method of Successive Averages (MSA)1 where each iteration has equal impact on the final result (default setting)

1Ortuzar, J., & Willumsen, L. G. (2002). Modelling Transport. John Wiley & Sons Inc.

Example 1


# Choose to run PLANit with a traditional static traffic assignment method
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

# set smoothing method to the Method of Succesive Averages
planit_instance.assignment.set(Smoothing.MSA)

# configure the instantiated property
planit_instance.assignment.smoothing.<call method>

item.title: Docs: VirtualCost.<Enum>
item.description:
Description

Class exposing the available Virtual Cost types as enums.

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, and instance.set(TrafficAssignment.<enum>) is invoked.

Then the physical cost type can be set on the assignment using instance.assignment.set(VirtualCost.<enum>) utilising one of the Enum Fields.

The instantiated object is the accessible via instance.assignment.virtualcost

It is possible that not every virtual cost method is supported by every traffic assignment method. The documentation of the chosen traffic assignment method will indicate what virtual cost methods are supported.

See also

Assignment for the various assignment methods where one can set the virtual cost on and how to retrieve the instantiated virtual cost object.

Type

Class VirtualCost in Enums.py

Fields

<enum> Fields Description
FIXED Apply a fixed cost to access the physical road network from a zone
SPEED Apply a fixed speed to all traffic accessing the physical road network from a zone

Example 1


# Choose to run PLANit with a traditional static traffic assignment method
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )

# set virtual cost to using a fixed value
planit_instance.assignment.set(VirtualCost.FIXED)

# configure the instantiated property
planit_instance.assignment.virtual_cost.<call method>

item.title: Docs: TrafficAssignment.<Enum>
item.description:
Description

Class exposing supported traffic assignment methods as enums.

Use

Assuming instance = PLANit() is available, you activate an output formatter via instance.activate(TrafficAssignment.<enum>). After this, the chosen assignment type can be accessed via instance.assignment

See also

PLANit.set(+)
PLANit.assignment

Type

Class TrafficAssignment in Enums.py

Fields

<enum> Fields Description Creates instance of
TRADITIONAL_STATIC Traditional static assignment implementation Traditional static assignment

Example 1


# set traditional static assignment as the assignment type
planit_instance = PLANit()
planit_instance.set(TrafficAssignment.TRADITIONAL_STATIC )
# access any method of the implementation via
planit_instance.assignment.<some method>
